title: opinion eu mess conservative
story: But we might not be able to leave the EU without an election.There is no getting around that dilemma. All the potential ­leadership contenders privately understand it, as do growing numbers of MPs.The question is whether they are brave enough to place such an unpopular truth before party members.When I predicted six weeks ago that the Conservative Party was headed for a single-figures vote in the European election unless it ditched Theresa May, there was much scoffing.Yes, I was told, things would be bad, but not that bad. Well, on Thursday, we secured . per cent.If we break that vote down by constituency, every single Tory MP loses.The first-past-the-post system is capricious. It protects you until, all of a sudden, it eliminates you.Just ask Scottish Labour.As long as our political debate revolves around Brexit, people are likely to vote for the most hardline pro and anti-Brexit parties.Indeed, the longer this wretched argument goes on, the more radicalised both sides become. Voters identy as Remain or Leave rather than according to their old party alignments.Three years ago, at the time of the referendum campaign, it was still a civil conversation rather than a civil war.The polarisation has come since the result, and it has become worse with every passing week.Most Leavers now want No Deal. Most Remainers want another referendum.The moment when both sides might have accepted a compromise — ideally a Swiss-type solution that would have taken us out of the EU’s political structures while retaining close economic links — has probably passed.So whose fault is it that we are in this situation  Hardliners on both sides must take their share of the blame.Those Remainers who promised to respect the result but then worked to frustrate it have done terrible damage to our politics.Those Leavers who, forgetting everything they said during the campaign, now insist that anything short of No Deal is a betrayal, have likewise destroyed trust in the system.But the chief responsibility lies with Theresa May.It was she who dug in on the wrong issues while conceding on the wrong issues, who mulishly insisted that it was all about immigration, who managed to convince both sides that she was secretly working for the other, who so aggravated EU leaders that, by the end, they were predisposed to reject anything she asked for because it was she who was doing the asking.Worst of all, she called and then lost the  election. From that moment, it was clear that our Parliament was prepared to frustrate Brexit.The EU got the message and started making deliberately absurd and vindictive demands, culminating in the Irish backstop which, incredibly, Theresa May accepted.We now face withdrawal terms so disadvantageous that they are worse than either staying or quitting — exactly as Michel Barnier intended.Which brings us back to the Catch-.Parliament does not intend to allow any government to leave the EU with No Deal, and the Commons Speaker has made clear that he is prepared to bend the rules in any way necessary to secure that end.In normal times, a Conservative leader would go to the country saying: “Give me the mandate I need. If Brussels knows we are ready for No Deal, we will get a good deal. We just need the numbers in Parliament.“Do you want me in charge, or a Marxist nostalgic who refuses to have a position on Brexit ”In normal times, such a leader would win comfortably. But these are not normal times.A large chunk of the electorate is now disposed to blame the Conservatives for the impasse rather than the parties that have actually been voting against Brexit.Nigel Farage has confirmed that he plans to contest every seat at the next election. The idea that he might stand aside in certain constituencies in order to stop Corbyn is based on a misunderstanding of how he operates.He is back at the head of a populist insurgent party.The last thing he wants is to have that party’s grievance addressed and so put himself out of business.Is there any solution  Possibly.It may be that Parliament cannot in fact block a No Deal Brexit. It may be that,forced to choose, MPs will baulk at voting to revoke Article .It may be that France, or another EU state, vetoes any extension beyond October  — though that is unlikely.Or it may be that the Tories could, in fact, win a general election.Perhaps I am wrong about Farage’s motivations, and he will agree to an electoral pact, fighting Labour in the North while standing aside in the South.Or maybe there’s another way out of the jam, one I can’t think of.But what cannot be denied is that the dilemma exists.There is no point in saying, “Just leave!” or “I’ll get us a better deal!” unless you are clear about how you intend to do it.The trouble is that, in the current mood, those are precisely the slogans that many Tory activists want to hear.The candidate who levels with them, who sets out the dilemma honestly and outlines a proposed route out of it, may become unelectable. As I say, Catch-.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: remainer john bercow remain speaker brexit
story: The move risks sparking a fresh rt with Eurosceptic Tories, who have accused him of using his supposedly neutral role in Parliament to try to keep Britain in the EU.Earlier this month, Bercow said he would be standing down and his words were taken to mean hed bow out at the summer recess, which starts in July.The Conservative MP said it was not sensible to vacate the chair” while Brexit remained unresolved.He told the : “I’ve never said anything about going in July of this year. Secondly, I do feel that now is a time in which momentous events are taking place and there are great issues to be resolved and in those circumstances, it doesn’t seem to me sensible to vacate the chair.”Bercow yesterday told a US audience it was “unimaginable” MPs won’t be able to act despite a No Deal exit being the legal default and warned there are years of debate ahead” on Brexit.The arch-Remainers words fly in the face of Tory leadership front runners Boris Johnson and Dominic Raab, who have both guaranteed the UK will leave the EU by Halloween - with or without a deal.Mr Bercow also fuelled the peoples vote campaign by suggesting MPs had the right to force a second referendum or even revoke Article .He said: They can’t be wished away or snfed at, but these matters were matters decided by the last Parliament. No Parliament can bind the hands of its successor. This Parliament can do as this Parliament thinks fit.Bercow broke his pledge to stand down by June last year.When he stood to be Speaker in  he promised only to serve for nine years but he has justied staying on longer because of the uncertainty caused by Brexit.But European Commission President Jean Claude Junker delivered a stark message to candidates in the race to replace Theresa May.Speaking to television cameras outside a summit in Brussels he said: There will be no renegotiation.The Eurocrats stubborn stance is bad news for Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunts Tory leadership bid. Yesterday, he said his Brexit policy was to try for renegotiation.Britain is on course to leave the EU on October  with or without a deal - unless the law is changed to extend further.There is currently no provision for MPs to amend the law to stop Britain leaving without a deal and leadership contenders such as Boris Johnson and Dominic Raab have warned they may end up going for it.But Mr Bercow’s comments yesterday signal he is willing to help create a way for MPs to block a No Deal Brexit.He said there was “no inevitability” about a No Deal Brexit and dismissed the suggestion that MPs had lost their chance to block No Deal once and for all.The only way to completely rule out a No Deal Brexit is for Britain to revoke Article .A request for a further extension could be blocked by just one EU member state - meaning Britain would leave without a deal on October .Speaking at the Brookings Institute in Washington DC, the Speaker said: “There is a dference between a legal default position and what the interplay of dferent political forces in parliament will facilitate.”He added: “The idea that parliament is going to be evacuated from the centre stage of debate on Brexit is unimaginable.”“The appetite for the house to have its say has recently been whetted and that appetite is not exhausted. Indeed some would say it’s voracious.“The house will want to have its say. The idea that the house will not have it say is for the birds. Parliament is a big player in this.“The idea that Parliament is going to be evacuated from the centre stage of debate on Brexit is unimaginable. It is simply unimaginable.”Tory MP Andrew Bridgen blasted: “This is further evidence -ever we needed it - of his Remain-supporting bias throughout the Brexit process. He’s a self-proclaimed Remainer who has ripped out every rule of impartiality from the Speaker’s rulebook.“Whoever the new leader of the Conservative party is will have to fight not only a Remain-dominated Parliament but also a Remain-supporting Speaker.”He added: “One thing’s for certain - John Bercow, the impartial Speaker, always has his say - everyday in Parliament, it’s almost like Speaker’s Question Time with Points of Order.”Ex-leader Iain Duncan Smith said: “In respect of the Speaker, we are subject to European law until the day we leave and European law is very clear that we leave on a set date unless a request for an extension is made and the EU grants that extension. That’s it.So Parliament only gets its say in terms of legislation, it can’t take over the Government at any stage, it can’t run the legislative programme, so it’s European law that will get the final say.”

title: king albert belgium dna test delphine boel lovechild
story: Lawyers said yesterday that Belgium’s former King Albert II, , has said he will take the test which will hopefully provide a breakthrough in the long-running case.King Albert II, who abdicated in  for health reasons, had been facing a daily fine of €,for failing to provide his DNA in the case brought by -year-old Delphine Boel.Boel has been trying to establish paternity for years and her story has often made headlines.Albert has never publicly denied being her father but so far had refused to provide DNA.A statement from Alberts lawyer, delivered to the Belgian media, said after the former monarch had taken note of the judgement two weeks ago, which imposed the daily fine, he would submit to the test out of respect to the judicial authorities.It was made clear the move did not imply any admission of guilt.Boels lawyer, Yves-Henri Leleu, said she reacted very positively, because with the DNA test, the biological evidence is now there.The lawyer for the former monarch said the DNA results would have to be sealed until later in the legal case.Rumours about Albert and Boels mother, Sybille de Selys Longchamps, , the aristocratic we of a well-heeled industrialist, have been around for years.But the news the king may have had a child with her broke out into the open when a biography of Alberts we, Queen Paola, was published in .He married Donna Paola Ruffo di Calabria in July  and they have two sons and one daughter.Delphine Boel, who was born in , first claimed she was Albert’s “lovechild” in .In June  Boel summoned the then King, the Duke of Brabant and the Archduchess of Austria-Este to appear in court, hoping DNA tests would prove her claims.However, being King at the time, Albert had complete immunity under the law.After Albert abdicated Boel dropped her initial law suit and filed a second one against him as he no longer had immunity.A court hearing in March  ruled that her claim was unfounded and her lawyers said she would appeal the decision.The Court of Appeal decided in October  that Boel was not a descendant of Jacques Boel and ordered the former king to undergo a DNA test.A lawyer for the king initially said he would seek further advice but earlier this year the lawyer initially stated he would not provide a DNA sample.In his Christmas message to the nation that year, King Albert indirectly confessed to a past infidelity and said he and Queen Paola lived through a crisis in the late s that almost wrecked their marriage but that a long while ago they overcame their marital problems.Six years ago Boel opened court proceedings to prove that Albert is her father.An artist and sculptor, Boel has always said that she brought the paternity case due to anger since she was being cold-shouldered by the royal family.

title: london bridge molotvo cocktails lidl rose wine
story: Rachid Redouane was filmed buying  bottles of rosé and three -inch knives two weeks before the attack.CCTV captured the jihadi casually browsing the aisles of the budget supermarket for £ ceramic blades in East Ham, East London.Eight people were killed when Khuram Butt, , Rachid Redouane, , and Youssef Zaghba, , drove a van into pedestrians and stabbed others in the rampage in London Bridge on June , .The terror gang also had an arsenal of weapons in the van, as well as blow torches and fake suicide vests.Texts found on one of the killers phones showed they originally intended to attack Oxford Street.Speaking today, acting Detective Chief Inspector Wayne Jolley told the Old Bailey: In most of the bottles other than one of them, the upper layer was petrol and the lower level was ethanol.Jonathan Hough QC, for the coroner, added: So they all had some kind of petroleum liquid inside them.The police officer explained that the flame grenades would have worked: The conclusion was they were viable.There were two blow torches, one of which had the branding name Go System.The wine bottles were purchased on the  May at the same Lidl where the knives had been purchased by Redouane.Redouane had bought three pink ceramic knives two weeks earlier on  May at Lidl in East Ham.Jolley said: There were segments of clothing found during the search of his home address.That clothing matched the wicks that were found in the bottles.There was also two, five litre bottles containing a similar amount of fuel type liquid.The inquest was told that Butt had planned to rent a much larger truck than the actual white Hertz van that the attackers were able to hire.Butt had requested a . tonne lorry but had been unable to collect it.The inquest was told the trio had loaded the BQ branded rental with  bags of gravel to increase the weight and make the attack more deadly.Mr Hough explained: That is I think a technique which has been recommended in some extremist publications for using vehicles as weapons.The officer told the inquest that as they drove from east London, the terrorists stopped at a petrol station and bought £. of diesel and also some drinks and snack bars.The inquest then heard about the fake suicide belts.DCI Jolley said: All of the belts consisted of four bottles, covered in silver duct tape attached to a brown belt.The bottles did not contain any liquid.Butt, Redouane and Zaghba were shot dead by police less than  minutes after their murderous attack began.Christine Archibald, , Xavier Thomas, , Sébastien Belanger, , Kirsty Boden, , James McMullan, , Sara Zelenak, , Alexandre Pigeard, , and Ignacio Echeverría, , were all killed in the attack.The inquest also heard the terrorists had been planning to attack Oxford Street but changed their minds at the last minute.

title: dad torturing kids shock collar rules
story: Takahiro Goto, , from the southern city of Kitakyushu , admitted to police he used the device to “discipline” the children when they “didn’t follow the rules”.He is also thought to have used a stun gun.Local police suspect Goto was in the habit of abusing his two stepdaughters, aged  and , and his biological son, , who is known to have suffered burns, local news source Asahi reported.The shock collar used by Goto was designed to be put around the neck of a dog and used with a remote control to stop the animal from barking too much.The packaging in which is it sold is labelled in English “Rechargeable and Waterproof Training Collar” and displays a picture of a dog.The abuse came to light when Goto’s eldest daughter told a teacher in February. The teacher told a child consultation centre, who then took the child under its protection, according to the Japan Times.Police are now investigating the possibility that Goto abused the children on a daily basis. It is thought the abuse began when his eldest stepdaughter was as young as five.Goto married his we, currently in her s, around  years ago and is currently unemployed, the Mainchi newspaper reported police as having said.The specic offence for which he was arrested took place between February  and  of this year, when it is alleged he used the shock collar on the arms of all three children.The case is the latest in a string of child abuse cases to have hit Japan in recent years, and on Tuesday the country’s lower house voted unanimously to ban the corporal punishment of children by their parents.In , the mother and stepfather of five-year-old Yua Funato were arrested when she died and was found to be bearing signs of malnutrition, and frostbite, and having been beaten.Prime minister Shinzo Abe described the death of Funato, who had been taken into protective custody on at least two occasions prior to her death, “soul-crushing”.The move will make Japan the third country in Asia, after Mongolia and Nepal, to introduce such bans in recent years.

title: man attempted lure girl sweets chase kidnap
story: The predator chased after the terried child and grabbed her by her hair after school in Wandsworth, south west London.Around :pm on Friday, November  , the little girl boarded a bus on Putney High Street.Then  minutes later, she got off the bus at Dover Park Drive where she noticed a man sitting at the stop.He started a conversation and tried to convince her to come home with him, promising her sweetsshe did so.She refused and ran away but he chased her down the road until she reached her home.As she got close to the house, the suspect grabbed her by the hair but she managed to get inside and close the door behind her, stopping him from entering.He is described as a tall black male, wearing dark clothing at the time of the incident.Detectives from the politan Polices South West CID are investigating and have released an image of a man they would like to speak to in connection with the incident.Detective Constable Matt Morse, leading the investigation, said: While incidents like this are rare we are very keen to trace this man and would urge anyone who can identy him to come forward.Anyone with information should call  with CAD reference  NOV.

title: monty python john cleese english city
story: The comic, , was echoing comments he made nearly a decade ago that also left critics fuming.Tweeting to his .million followers, he wrote: Some years ago I opined that London was not really an English city any more[.]Since then, virtually all my friends from abroad have confirmed my observation[.]So there must be some truth in it... I note also that London was the UK city that voted most strongly to remain in the EU.His isive words left many social media users baffled about his concept of one of the most erse cities in the world.Times journalist David Aaronovitch corrected him, tweeting: London has long been a British city, John.Which you might expect, what with it being the capital.Comedian Dom Joly was also among those blasting the racist and hypocritical claims.“He’s clearly a really smart funny man but it is basically a very racist tweet, Joly wrote.Secondly, its a racist tweet by a man who lives on a Caribbean island – the irony of that is insane.Cleese vowed to leave the UK for the Caribbean last year, blaming the awful quality of the Brexit debate.But some came to the funnymans defence, including Twitter user Sweetest Dreams Escape wrote: As a black Briton who’s proud to serve my nation and defend free speech, why is he being racist  NOTHING HE’S SAID IS RACIST! And he has as much right to say this as people have the right to extol the virtues of multicultural London, which HAS lost its identity.The Fawlty Towers stars comments came eight years after telling Australian TV he didnt know whats going on in Britain.He told an audience at the time: Let me say this, I don’t know what’s going on in London because London is no longer an English city.“I love having dferent cultures around but when the parent culture kind ofMore than  languages are spoken in London, where non-white ethnic groups make up more than  per cent of the citys population.

title: sherpas haul frozen corpse
story: The corpses gloved arm stf and sticking out from the blankets has been issued as a warning to climbers before they take on the worlds highest peak.The rigid body was carried away by the three sherpas who seemed to struggled with the weight of the man in the harsh temperatures and altitude.The video was posted by Rotash Khileri to show other climbers just how dangerous the mountain can be.On Instagram he wrote: This video teaches every climber a lot. We must understand this situation.Sherpas are the form of a God in the mountains.We should respect them. And should also respect the mountains. If we have a slight problem in the mountains.So you should talk to Sherpa quickly. And should get back down from the mountain.We can not fight with nature. We must not risk our lives.Because there is also our family who is waiting at home.So you take care of yourself.The flat part of the summit is around the size of two ping-pong tables but now the season has begun it can become packed with  climbers taking pictures just inches from a several-thousand foot drop.So far,  people have died in  days as they attempted to reach the top of the , ft mountain.Christopher Kulish, an experienced climber, died on Monday of a reported heart attack.Ed Dohring, from Arizona, had spend his  le dreaming of completing the arduous climb, compared the worlds highest peak to a zoo and said that it was scary.He described a large group of people who were already at the summit as very rude and unruly and that they were basically pushing so they could get better pictures of themselves.Speaking to CBS, he said: I was surprised at how many people were, you know, above , feet and were really obviously either not fit or not experienced and probably shouldnt have been there.I certainly wasnt prepared to pass dead bodies that were attached to the safety line. It was very dficult.Anjali Sharad Kulkarni, , who lived in Mumbai, was among three Indians who died as they attempted to climb the worlds highest mountain, which has seen  deaths already this season.All of the deaths this year have occurred during peak climbing season and has been the deadliest year since  when  climbers died.Officials have issued  permits to tourists and a further  to Nepalese mountaineers to climb the mountain this year after growing safety fears.Experienced climbers expressed concerns over the overcrowding and adventure companies offering cheap packages to unsuitable climbers - resulting in blocking the path.Elia Saikaly, a film maker, said that as he watched the sunrise  it unmasked the dead body of another climber.In an Instagram post he wrote: I cant believe what I saw up there.Death. Carnage. Chaos. Lineups. Dead bodies on the route in tents at camp . People who I tried to turn back ended up dying. People being dragged down. Walking over bodies. Everything you read in the sensational headlines all played out on our summit night. Elia told : There were  plus climbers making their way up to the summit.After first walking in t-shirts, as they get further up the temperature drastically changes, the Himalayan wind icy.Every few moments she had to stop to regain her breath, claiming that each step she took was an effort.She began to feel unwell a few hours before reaching Base Camp and considered turning back. She felt that she had come down with a cold or chest infection.But once she arrived at Base Camp she said that climbers were crying, complaining of lack of sleep, headaches, dizziness.She was checked by guides and locals who said that her oxygen saturation was low but her heart rate was high.The next day she set off at a slow pace, but after stumbling along the path her guide said she had acute mountain sickness and she was taken off the mountain by emergency helicopter.If altitude sickness is ignored, it can lead to le-threatening conditions affecting the brain or lungs. I came across a deceased climber... that persons body was fixed to an anchor point between two safety lines and every single person that was climbing towards the summit had to step over that human being.It’s dficult for people at sea-level, who are not mountaineers, who have never been above , metres, to understand that particular scenario. When you are on Everest and you’re in the death zone and you can barely think … it becomes a very complicated situation and you realise in your mind that your fate could be the same.And with a line-up pushing you up the mountain there nothing you can do. You really have no choice but to carry on.He also said how he spotted a man clutching his chest and bent over. Elia went to help and checked his oxygen mask, which was working fine.The man was shaking, pale and couldnt speak and died on the mountain that night.American John Kulish, , died at South Col on the descent from the summit of Mount Everest on Monday.Most of the deaths on Everest this year have been attributed to exhaustion and tiredness, exacerbated because a crowded route to and from the summit has led to delays.British climber Robin Haynes Fisher, , died on the mountain just hours after warning overcrowding on the mountain could be fatal.He was m from the top of the worlds highest mountain when he collapsed in the so-called death zone, which is known for having low levels of oxygen.Fisher chillingly revealed on social media how he had changed his plans to avoid the crowds on Everest just hours before he died on the descent.Robin is the tenth person to die on Everest this season - with most suffering weakness, exhaustion and delays on the crowded route to the summit.Dad-of-two Kevin Hynes died earlier this week as he attempted to scale the Everest summit.The -year-old, from Galway, Ireland, was coming from the Tibetanside on Friday morning as part of a team of six along with three expert sherpas.Since then more , people have reached the summit, according to the Himalayan Database.Jordan Romero, from the US became the youngest person to climb Everest aged  and  months in , while in  an -year-old Japanese man Yuichiro Miura became the oldest.Nearly  people have died trying to climb the famous mountain since the first attempt to scale it in .The deaths that have perhaps grabbed the most attention over the years were those of George Malloryand Andrew Sandy Irvine.They disappeared in  after setting off for the summit with only primitive gear and there has been endless speculation they were in fact the first to the top.Mallory’s body was discovered in  but that failed to resolve the mystery.Many of the corpses are buried under the snow but melting glaciers are exposing bodies once entombed in ice on the worlds highest graveyard.

title: jacob rees mogg no deal not big deal
story: The sheer enthusiasm of Brexit Party voters for leaving cleanly no later than October  and their frustration that the United Kingdom is still in the European Union proved that we are not a nation to be cowed.EvenTheresa May never really believed it, the nation took to heart her message that No Deal is better than a bad deal.And the people, with their characteristic good sense, are right.Fortunately, there is no legal obligation, as set out in the House of Lords report, to pay the EU any money at allwe leave without a deal.That means we have £billion to spend on our priorities rather than squandering it on the EU’s wasteful and consistently unaudited budget.This could be used for tax cuts to encourage business investment. The rates burden could be reduced or stamp duty cut.There may even be some room for expenditure in pressing areas such as social care for the elderly or helping the hard-pressed police.£billion is a serious amount of money which could have a signicant domestic effect rather than being little more than overseas aid for rich ­countries.Then we could trade with the EU on the basis of the World Trade Organisation . This provides a framework for treating countries fairly. The UK, in spite of allowing the EU to represent our interests in recent years, has always been a founder member, and as soon as we have left we may resume our rightful place.The WTO allows nations to set tarfs that will then be applied to all other members in the absence of specic free trade deals.The concept of “most favoured nation” means that it is unlawful to discriminate against one country.The effect of this is that the EU could not charge higher tarfs against us than it does on goods from the United States.As the US has seen its trade with the EU grow faster since the introduction of the Single Market than the UK’s has, it is clearly no barrier to successful ­business.Likewise, the UK would have to levy the same payments on EU goods as we do on others — and here we would have a choice.Would we want to lower tarfs generally, cutting the cost of goods for ­consumers, or keep the protectionist ­barriers that make Europe so expensive It seems obvious that we ought to cut tarfs to improve living standards, ­especially for the least well-off in society, allowing them to have more money to save or spend.Historically, nations that have cut the cost of imports have become more prosperous and there are non-tarf barriers that the EU imposes purely to protect inefficient continental industries that could also be removed.Against this opportunity there are many myths that have grown up, fed and watered by those who never wanted to leave the EU.First, they say that the WTO has other agreements tacked on — over  with the US alone — and without them trade would stall.This is a misunderstanding.These add-ons include treaties such as the Paris Climate Accord which are not trade-related.Only about  have any trade relevance of which only one is important and it has already been rolled over.As they are purely technical, rolling them over is not dficult as has already been shown.Other doomsters say that just-in-time delivery cannot work under WTO — which is odd, as it already does.What matters for these processes is certainty of delivery times.The six ­seconds that it takes goods to clear customs in Southampton on average is insignicant compared to potential delays on the M which businesses already have to contend with.The UK already trades extensively and successfully on a WTO basis so ­extending it to the EU would not be problematic.The paranoid and the scaredy-cats also moan that more checks would have to be made, but again that is incorrect.Jon Thompson, the chief executive of Customs and Excise, confirmed that delays would be no worse than they ­currently are for imports.There is no WTO rule to create inefficiencies. The purpose of the organisation is the reverse. The system of cross-border trade is not that which people imagine from watching s spy films.In addition, both Calais and Dover, the only real pinch points, are both prepared and ready for No Deal.As for Ireland, the simple question remains: Who is going to build the wall There will be no hard border because no one wants one and that has always been the simple answer to a much over-complicated question.In truth the fears are like the supposed Millennium Bug, a fantasy of fevered minds.After all, with £billion, free-flowing trade and cheaper imports, as former Trade and Industry Secretary Peter ­Lilley has said: “It is not crashing out, it is cashing in.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says john bercow needs to go
story: John Bercow has spent months putting centuries of Parliamentary convention through the shredder with one goal in mind: to stop Brexit and overturn the largest democratic vote in our history.The Speaker’s role demands impartiality. Our fragile “unwritten constitution” relies on the good faith of iniduals. Bercow’s bias risks the whole thing collapsing.Of course, we shouldn’t be surprised that this political pygmy has now shamelessly decided to stay on.He didn’t resign when it became apparent he’d allowed a bullying culture to prosper under his watch.He didn’t resign when he was accused of physically intimidating staff.Nor did he go when he appeared to call a female Cabinet Minister — who has risen to heights he can only dream of — a stupid woman.According to tradition, Speakers have to be dragged to the Chair by MPs. With this one they’ll have to take the Chair out of the Commons with him still in it before we see the back of him.For years, Bercow’s bloated ego was written off as just tiresome Parliamentary panto from a man so painfully self-centred he would have been in the first leboat off the Titanic. title: dwp change disability benefits begins
story: NewsDWP: Change to disability benefits begins this Friday - but theres a major catchPIP pensioners will stop facing re-tests for their benefits - but despite a pledge to help them "from Spring", , disabled pensioners are still in the lurchShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPIP claimants over  will stop facing re-tests for their benefits. But when  "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA reform to stop re-testing disabled pensioners for their benefits will launch this Friday, the DWP has announced. In future any Personal Independence Paymentclaimants over  will face only a “light touch” review once a decade - instead of stressful full eligibility tests every few years. But charities slammed the DWP for admitting this weekaposs launch is only a partial step. Currently the change will only apply to new claimants who start claiming PIP from Friday onwards. Almost , pensioners who already claim PIP are still waiting for a date when their re-tests will end.    In March, when the reform was unveiled, a DWP press release said their re-tests would end “from Spring of this year”. And Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd said the move was imminent. But officials now say the , existing claimants will be brought into the reform “in the coming months”.  There is still no confirmed date. It is thought the DWP is aiming to include existing claimants from the summer. Genevieve Edwards of the MS Society said it was really disappointing that the pledge has been delayed for existing claimants. She added: There are more than , people with MS over the state pension age already claiming PIP. They shouldnapost have to keep going through this stressful process for no apparent reason.  While it’s clearly welcome for new claimants, we know thousands of people who are already on PIP have lost support because assessments don’t work for unpredictable conditions like MS. Vicki Nash of mental health charity Mind added: It’s good news that some new claimants of PIP won’t have to be reassessed for health conditions that aren’t going to change signicantly over the long-term. But this announcement doesn’t go far enough for the hundreds of thousands of people still facing mandatory reassessments. We want to see more people being awarded longer-term PIP payments so they don’t have to face the stress of reassessments. Unless there’s strong evidence that a person’s health has changed, there’s just no need for a series of face-to-face assessments.  Pensioners can only claim PIPthey were already on the benefit, or its predecessor DLA, when they reached the state pension age. New claimants over the state pension age must apply for Attendance Allowance instead. That means this Fridayaposs reform will affect very few people at first. People will only be saved repeat assessmentsthey started claiming PIP from Friday onwards and were under pension age at the time and then reach pension age later on. DWP sources insisted they were moving quickly to roll out the reform in full.  Work and Pensions Secretary Amber Rudd said: Stopping unnecessary PIP reviews for people over State Pension age is a positive change. It applies a common-sense approach to treating those whose conditions are unlikely to change. And we want to introduce it as quickly as possible for those who will benefit from it. Minister for Disabled People Justin Tomlinson said: Stopping needless PIP reviews for pensioners is the right thing to do. This step means new claimants to PIP who reach State Pension age before their review is due won’t have one unless they tell us their needs have changed. The next step is to bring this in for all pensioners.

title: tory leadership what candidates prime
story: NewsTory leadership: What do the candidates for Prime Minister think about everything but BrexitAs the race to replace Theresa May at No heats up weve tried to workout where they stand and what their key policies areShareCommentsByOliver MilnePolitical Correspondent:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsWith the race hotting up, what do they actually think about the issues effecting the UK "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Basically every Conservative MP who thinks they can get through a television appearance without accidentally revealing their pin number is standing in the race to replace Theresa May .There are eleven candidates in the race for the top job.Theyaposve all been pretty clear about what they think about Brexit .You can read our guide to what they think about the biggest constitutional issue in modern British history here. But once elected they wonapost just be the Brexit Prime Minister. Their inbox will be overflowing with a range of issues that will demand action and decision making from the heart of British government. So what have the Conservatives standing to be the next party leader, and PM, said are their policy priorities except for Brexit  The Tory frontrunner is staying tight-lipped about what he might actually think when it comes to policy. Perhaps not surprising for a man who famously wrote two op-eds, one Leave and one Remain, before deciding who to back in the  referendum. It is also born out of political necessity. If you ask Tory insiders they say that Mr Johnson will win any race IF he gets to the final two, after Tory MPs whittle down the herd. But across Westminster MPs have spent time building up doubts about the straw-haired showman. So while the others are flouting their policy credentials, Mr Johnson is quietly trying to shore up support among his colleagues in Parliament. Dominic Raab    The former Brexit Secretary is a favourite among some of the Conservative Partyaposs members who think George Osborneaposs austerity drive was a bit socialist. He has already promised to shrink the state and slash public spending. It is a move that is certain to be popular with the well-fed Tories of SW, but not with Britainaposs cash strapped public services. He wants to reduce the basic rate of income tax from p to p over time - including a p drop straight away - and lower national insurance by raising the threshold. Mr Raab claimed there was £bn of headroom in the public finances to make the move. But he also admitted itaposd involve slashing back government through efficiency savings - a front often used for cuts in David Cameronaposs era. He told the BBC: We would have a spending review... cut down the number of Whitehall departments, cut out the bureaucracy, Iaposd have a special commission looking at public sector procurement particularly in the NHS and MOD. Then I would recycle roughly half of that into frontline services - teachers, schools, nurses - and half of that into the tax cuts for the future. Rory Stewart    The International Development Secretary has said Britain lacks serious people in politics with serious approaches to solve our problems. So perhaps not surprisingly he has one of the most developed policy s in the race, and perhaps the most eccentric way of communicating it Mr Stewart has been walking around public places inviting people to take part in debates in a bid to demonstrate his belief that the Tories need to reach out to people who might previously have ignored the party. He has pledged to double spending on climate change and the environment as he warned the UK must do more in the face of an environmental cataclysm. The International Development Secretary warned a million species could be lost and  million more people could be plunged into poverty unless more is done. Speaking on Sky News, Mr Stewart also said he would double the UKaposs diplomatic budget and completely reframe the intelligence services. Esther McVey    The former welfare slasher - who once branded the rise of food banks positive and defended the vile Bedroom Tax - has vowed to target public sector workers and low earners for votes. She has vowed to cut taxes - without saying which - and slash £billion from the foreign aid budget and spend it on school and police.But she refused to match Labour ’s pledge to hire , police officers after the Tories slashed more than , since  - claiming it was a “gimmicky figure”.Matt Hancock    The Health Secretary and former advisor to George Osborne have said he would lead Britain in a digital revolution - saying he has the youth and energy to transform Britainaposs economy to work in the st century. He has also hit out at the what he claimed was growing hostility to business in the Conservative party. Mr Hancock told the Financial Times that the Conservatives should be backing business not bashing business as he said: To the people who say ‘f**k business’, I say ‘f**k, f**k business’. Speaking to the BBC he felt so strongly about business because that is where I came from. His family wrote the software which helps websites find your address when you type in your postcode. Michael Gove    Environment Secretary Michael Gove has pushed a successful,small scale, policy agenda at his current department. Plastic straws, drink stirrers and cotton buds will be banned in the UK from next April under a green policy agenda spearheaded by Mr Gove. He has also said he will offer free British citizenship to three million eligible EU nationalshe becomes Prime Minister. It will see him waive the £, fee to EU nationals living in the UK at the time of the  referendum. It is believed there are around three million people who this would apply to once they have been a British resident for five year Jeremy Hunt    Still relatively policy light, Mr Hunt has been stepping slightly outside his brief in the last few weeks as part of his leadership bid. The Foreign Secretary used a major policy speech to the Lord Mayor’s Banquet at London’s Mansion House to back calls for extra cash for the military - a key plea from high-profile Conservative backbenchers. Britain is one of a handful of NATO nations to meet the alliance benchmark of pumping % of GDP into its Armed Forces – and a host of prominent Tory backbenchers want a lt. Many see it as a rallying point for hawkish right-wingers, and a potential party leadership candidate would boost their hopes by pressing for a rise. Warning of the mounting threats from “more aggressive Russia and a more assertive China”, Mr Hunt said: “I believe it is time for the next Strategic Defence and Security Review to ask whether, over the coming decade, we should decisively increase the proportion of GDP we devote to defence. Andrea Leadsom    The former leader of the House of Commons may have precipitated Theresa Mayaposs resignation - and she has strong views on Brexit. But since the race launched she hasnapost said much about what she thinks about anything . Sajid Javid    The Home Secretary has spent much of his political career picking high profile fights with other Conservatives, most notably Theresa May. In that vein, he has come out and said he would partially reverse swingeing Tory cuts to the police and recruit , police officers. He said the move would cost £billion. He has also claimed he would slash red tape to make it easier for police to tackle the rising kne crime on Britainaposs streets. But as Home Secretary Mr Javid has come in for heavy criticism for, among other moves, stripping Isis terror teen Shamina Begum and her newly born baby.Shadow Home Secretary Diane Abbott wrote on Twitter : It is against international law to make someone stateless, and now an innocent child has died as a result of a British woman being stripped of her citizenship.This is callous and inhumane. Kit Malthouse    Housing Minister Kit Malthouse was part of the  intake of Tory MPs and brokered the so-called aposMalthouse compromiseapos Brexit plan - which basically was just Hard Brexit by another name. Unveiling his leadership campaign in The Sun he seemed to suggest a big policy agenda was coming. He said he would pitch himself as a new face, with fresh new ideas, from a new and talented generation. Mr Malthouse vowed to do more to boost green technology, tackle youth violence and turn the Conservatives into the party of well-funded schools - a thinly-veiled swipe at government cuts to school budgets. But he has so far been principle heavy and detail light. James Cleverly  The former Tory deputy chair vowed to offer “something dferent and something new in the campaign. But hasnapost come forward with much yet.

story: NewsFamily who won chance to live on remote island leave after son injured on first dayThe Scharers three year stint as wardens on Bardsey Island, off North Wales, started in disastrous fashion when Sam was hurt soon after arrivingShareByDavid Coleman:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsFarmer Ned, , and his we Sophie, , with kids Sam, , and Rowan,  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family who won a competition to start a new le on a remote island have given up on their dream - after an accident on day one. The Scharer family beat  other finalists to move to the idyllic Bardsey Island off North Wales to work as wardens. Farmer Ned, , and his we Sophie, , were due to spend three years on the island managing the nature reserve, a farm and bird observatory with their two children. But on day one -year-old son Sam fell shortly after stepping off the boat and was taken to hospital with a leg injury - and went home with his mum to heal. Ned was left to manage the island on his own and lasted a little over a month, but quickly realised the task ahead was too much for him.  Mrs Scharer said: It was such a shame but in the end, it made the decision to leave the island easier for us because we effectively had no choice. What happened was just one of those things. It could have happened anywhere. Mrs Scharer said Sam had slipped on rocks and had to be taken to hospital by helicopter where he was treated for a leg injury. She said: The warden has a direct line to the coastguard, so even though youaposre on the island, you have this amazing back-up. The seas were too rough to launch the boat so they sent the helicopter.    Sam has only recently healed but he now has a beautul scar in the shape of the island. Itaposs a wonderful souvenir. She said husband Ned found maintaining the island - which has , visitors each year - proved too much for him, and the family have now ed home to Llanwrst in Snowdonia. The mile-long island is known as the Island of , Saints and is said to be the final resting place of thousands of pilgrims. It is now famed for its wildle and rugged scenery - attracting seals, Manx shearwaters, porpoises and dolphins.    Bardsey Island Trust is now seeking new wardens to manage the remote island for the next three years. Wardens are paid an £, salary and offered accommodation and utilities on the island. According to the trust, candidates must be physically fit, comfortable with isolation - and prepared for no phone signal.  Mrs Scharer said: Itaposs an amazing opportunity for a family who love to spend time together and to have an adventure. The isolation is an attraction for many but itaposs incredibly social in terms of the community.You have to be pretty hardy to put up with the weather and work - but we were lucky to live somewhere so beautul.It certainly was an experience.

story: NewsHarry Potter named most inspirational childrens book character in top  listAlso winning the hearts of young readers were Mary Poppins, Paddington Bear and Peter PanShareCommentsByAlice Hughes:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video survey-sees-harry-potter-named-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News , options :,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,irisClientToken:,externalBrandCSS:true,irisTvEnabled:true,imaVersion:,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,amazonVideoTagEnabled:true,amazonTagEnabled:true,mvtTests:,video.suppressDates:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJ.K Rowling’s Harry Potter has been named the most inspirational children’s book character – beating fellow Hogwarts student Hermione Granger to the top spot. The young wizard won the hearts of readers throughout the seven book instalments, after discovering his magical powers at the age of . Harry went on to fight off Dementors, trolls and giant spiders - which were later brought to le through box office hits. Coming in at second was Roald Dahl’s uber intelligent Matilda, closely followed by the author’s loveable protagonist Charlie Bucket from Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.  The poll of , parents highlights the importance of parental relationships and reading, with many characters and books being passed down through generations. Also making the top  inspirational children’s characters were Mary Poppins, Paddington Bear and Peter Pan. Residents of A.A. Milne’s Hundred Acre Wood proved popular, with Winnie the Pooh, Christopher Robin and Tigger all featuring in the list. The survey was commissioned by The Works, which is supporting parents in helping their children embrace reading.  Dr Jane Murray, who specialises in early childhood education, said on behalf of The Works: “The research shows how books are as important as ever and the positive impact they have on a child’s development and relationship with their parents and other carers. “At the heart of every story there is a good character and the research shows how nostalgic and classic characters continue to inspire parents and children throughout le. “It’s great to see how adults are helping their children to embrace reading and discover fictional worlds and characters who can influence their child’s behaviour and outlook.”  The research also found the most inspirational book titles included The BFG, Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland and The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe. On average, parents read with their children five times a week and six in  said they really enjoy this time spent with their youngsters. Over half have made ‘story time’ a part of their kids’ bedtime routine most nights, which explains why the most common place to read to them is in the child’s bed.  A further  per cent admit they think it’s important for children to have inspirational characters to look up to in stories and four in  typically try to read books along these lines. Over one third have read a book they loved from their own childhood to their offspring, and  per cent of modern kids ‘loved’ the classic read. Despite this, more parents said today’s books are better than their own youthful stories.  The study proved how reading is still vital to parent and child relationships today, with four in five stating it is one of the best ways to bond with their kids. Almost two thirds admitted they will miss reading with their children once they’re too old. Half of those polled, via OnePoll, said they have had to read ‘lots’ of books over and over again at their child’s demand, with three in  even knowing a book off heart as they’ve read it so many times.  The average amount of times a parent has re-read their child’s favourite book to them is an astonishing . The most popular titles to read multiple times were found to be The Very Hungry Caterpillar, The Gruffalo and We’re Going on a Bear Hunt. Dr Murray added: “Books not only help children to learn, but they also help them to be happier.    A survey of more than , children found that the more books a child owns, the more likely they are to be doing well at school and to be happy with their lives. “Babies attune to the human voice to help them to learn, so when a parent and young child focus together on a book, for example, pointing at pictures and repeating the words together, their joint attention helps the young child to develop important knowledge and skills about language and reading.” Top  inspirational characters from children’s books:Harry Potter Matilda Charlie Bucket, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory Hermione Granger, Harry Potter novels by J.K. story: NewsHunt for man who tried to lure girl, , with sweets on way home from schoolA man struck up conversation with the girl at a bus stop in Wandsworth, London, before chasing her home and attempting to grab her by the hair, police sayShareCommentsByMargaret DavisAbigail OLeary:,  MAY NewsThe girl got off the bus after school and was followed home by a man, police say "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPolice are investigating the attempted kidnap of a nine-year-old girl who was lured with sweets as she travelled home from school. title: man who swerved avoid octopus
story: NewsMan who swerved to avoid an OCTOPUS on the road was actually high on drugsRobert Shapley, , pretended to read an imaginary book about hedgehogs after mumbling to police about ious sea creatures on the roadShareCommentsByTom Bevan:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsRobert Shapley crashed after seeing an octopus on the A"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA driver who told police his car overturned because he swerved to avoid an octopus had taken a cocktail of drugs, a court heard. Robert Shapley, , mumbled to police at the scene about ious sea creatures being on the road, and later pretended to read an imaginary book about hedgehogs. He pleaded guilty to driving while unfit through drugs when he appeared at Newton Abbot Magistrates’ Court. Police who attended on February  said he was incoherent and mumbled to them about whitebait, octopus and other sea creatures on the road. Shortly after the crash a prankster put up a cut-out of an octopus on a stick in a field close to the crash site - which led to some suggesting the driver may have been telling the truth.  But the court heard Shapley, of Salcombe, Devon, was in fact high on drugs at the time. He told officers: “It got a bit bumpy for a while. I swerved to avoid an octopus” and “it is pretty bad out there having to dodge all that whitebait”. Officers said they found no evidence of an octopus on the road. Philip Sewell, prosecuting, said the crash happened at a junction after Shapley’s car overtook another. His car ended up on its roof in a ditch on the A between Malborough and South Milton.  “He was stumbling around, he wasn’t coherent,” Mr Sewell said. Police were called at about .pm and put him in one of their cars before he was checked over by paramedics. “He continued to talk to the officers, he was talking about squid, octopus and other sea creatures,” Mr Sewell said, adding that he later pretended to be reading an imaginary book about hedgehogs. The drugs in Shapley’s system included morphine, codeine, cannabis, and a by-product of heroin. Simon Colman, defending, said Shapley suffered from depression and anxiety and took prescription drugs and heroin, but did not remember taking anything prior to driving. Magistrates said they took a “very dim view” of his driving and adjourned the case for a report to be prepared about whether he was suitable for a drug rehabilitation requirement.

title: model who exploited given weekly
story: NewsBullies, body-shaming and weekly weighs-ins: Model reveals dark side of fashionLeanne Maskell, originally from Coventry, West Midlands, wrote The Model Manesto in which she describes her horric ordeal in the fashion industryShareCommentsByElizabeth Archer:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsLeanne Maskell was a model for around  years "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAs a teenage model, Leanne Maskell thought she was embarking on a glamorous career. Instead, she faced exploitation and abuse. She tells us her story... Standing in her bedroom with a tape measure wrapped around her hips, Leanne Maskell fought back tears. No matter how little she ate, she was never thin enough for her modelling agency. But at ft in and a size eight, she’d nothing left to lose. “It was horrible. I was told I wouldn’t get any work unless I lost three centimetres from my hips. “But there was no way for me to lose that kind of weight without starving myself,” says Leanne, . Leanne began modelling at  after her mum sent a picture to an agency. She worked for some of ­fashion’s top brands, appeared in British and French Vogue, and walked the catwalks at fashion weeks in Paris and London. But despite her success, the pressures of modelling left Leanne suffering anxiety.    Now she wants to lt the lid on an industry she says is re with bullying, sexual abuse and exploitation. As a child, Leanne never considered a career in modelling. Years of playground bullying left her with low self-esteem. So she was stunned when a modelling agency wanted her. “I went from being the girl who was bullied to the girl who was a model. It was great,” she says.    But her dad was worried from the outset. “He wanted to cut my hair off so I couldn’t model any more,” she says. “He was wary and didn’t want me to be a part of it so young.” And with good reason. As a teen, Leanne was subjected to weekly weigh-ins and was forced to send food diaries to her agency. She lost weight, but struggled with anorexia and bulimia. While studying law at university she modelled on the side. But beneath the glamour, Leanne was earning barely any money. She explains that it’s common practice for models to sign power of attorney to their agency to sign contracts for them. This means the agency can rack up debt in the model’s name.  “They book shoots, hair appointments and travel for models. Without asking, the agency will loan the model the money, then start charging interest,” she says. “I told the agency I didn’t want them to lend me any money without me knowing, but within the first week I owed £,. They booked me on shoots I had to pay for myself, then added interest. “When I complained, they said: ‘It’s not debt, it’s an investment in your career’.” In the end, Leanne became so anxious her GP advised her to leave the agency. “It was making me ill,” she says. On top of this, she says there was no protection against predatory men. “Once, I had a horrible shoot with a guy in his bedroom,” Leanne recalls. “He tried to make me take my clothes off and I didn’t want to, so I ran to the bathroom and called my agent, who told me to leave. It was scary and horrible.” Another time Leanne was being harassed on social media by a porn photographer. So she was horried when her agents booked her on a shoot with him. “The shoot was at his house. I was furious and refused to go. I couldn’t believe they’d booked it without checking him out.”  Leanne says sexual abuse is common. “People want you to pose sexually or kiss other models, ­especially at castings. “You’re expected to get naked in front of people as a matter of course. You feel like an object.” Leanne quit modelling for good this year and is now a legal policy adviser. She is keen to expose the dark side of modelling, saying “I want to stop others being taken advantage of”. She says a lot of the time fashion images are misleading. “I was doing shoots for fashion magazines when I was . “The models people compare themselves to are teenagers and children a lot of the time. It’s an unrealistic image,” she says. Since quitting, Leanne is much happier. “I feel so much better about myself and my body now,” she says. “I’d never join a modelling agency again. It’s nice to go to work and not have people scrutinising how I look.”The Model Manesto by Leanne Maskellis out now.

title: monster mum dad put children
story: NewsMonster mum and dad put children through worst abuse police had ever seenThe mum and dad kept one of their sons locked naked in a faeces-covered room and squeezed his genitals as punishmentShareByArun LalChris kitching:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsPolice say it was one of the worst cases they have ever seen"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn evil mother and father who horrically abused their children in one of the worst cases of child cruelty police have ever seen have been jailed. The monster couple, who cannot be named to protect their children, kept one of their sons locked naked in a squalid excrement-covered bedroom with no mattress or light bulb. The boy was also subjected to beatings, having his genitals squeezed as punishment, and fed scraps of food left by the other children in the house. His siblings were ordered to beat their brother as a punishment and they themselves were made to sleep on bare, dirty mattresses with springs poking out of them. This all happened while the couple, from Northampton, slept in their own clean, fully-furnished bedroom and kept several perfectly usable mattresses locked in a spare bedroom. The parents - who abused the children over a seven year period - showed no emotion after they were convicted of six counts of wilful neglect and child cruelty at Northampton Crown Court.     The father was jailed for a total of  years to run concurrently meaning he will actually serve seven years behind bars. The mother was sentenced to a total of . years but will serve just three and a half years in prison. The court heard that when police raided the coupleaposs home in  they found one of the boyaposs bedroom covered in excrement. A lock and an exterior alarm were fixed to the door and the blind over the curtain was nailed in place. Jailing the couple, His Honour Judge Michael Fowler said: It was nothing less than a cell. When the jury first saw the photographs of the conditions in which [that boy] was kept, they must have wondered what explanation you could advance for what they were looking at. And you could do nothing but tell obvious lies and ignore the reality of the offending. During the five-week trial, the father claimed he did not realise the extent of filthy, unhygienic conditions in the boyaposs bedroom. The judge called this defence fancul, and the jury took only three hours to convict the pair. Addressing the father, the judge said: The children in this case have suffered serious psychological, developmental and emotional harm. He told the pair: Both of you were found guilty of the most serious offences on this indictment. Central to this case is the horric cruelty shown to one boy in particular and it is dficult to contemplate anything much worse than the circumstances in which he was kept. You managed to conceal the extent of your neglect and abuse and you chose to home school a child, a process which is a complete farce, without having the necessary ability or equipment to do so. In fact, no schooling took place and it was during this period of so-called home schooling the neglect of this child reached its height. Not only did you abuse him but you encouraged his siblings to join in. All the children involved have suffered severe emotional and psychological harm at your hands, having been subjected to multiple acts of violence and cruelty over a long period of time. Speaking after the case, Detective Constable Nicky Webb, of Northamptonshire Police, said: In  years of working in Child Protection I have never before encountered abuse and neglect on this scale. title: right wing tories wrong voice
story: NewsopinionRight-wing Tories have got it so wrong on ugly mission to turbo-charge ThatcherAfter nine years of austerity we now faces the prospect of a Prime Minister who will shrink the state still furtherShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsopinionDominic Raab is putting his hat in the ring to be new Tory leader "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe don’t know who will win the Tory leadership race, but we do know who will be the losers – those who work for and rely on our public services. The candidates are already engaged in a bidding war to deliver the most right-wing agenda. Contenders such as Dominic Raab have promised to put tax cuts ahead of ­investment in schools and hospitals. His rivals will no doubt join this unpalatable Dutch auction as they seek to win the backing of a reactionary Tory membership. After nine years of austerity inflicting unprecedented cuts on our public services, the country now faces the prospect of a Prime Minister who will shrink the state still further. It is galling enough to see senior Tories neglect the day job in an egotistical pursuit of power. But it is frightening to think the winner could take the country further to the right on a mission to turbo-charge Thatcherism. This is not a beauty pageant, but an ugly race to the bottom that will leave the country poorer, meaner and more unequal. Who cares  While the Tories indulge in yet another leadership contest, vital areas of reform are left on the wayside. This is especially the case when it comes to caring for the elderly. Despite repeated promises we are still no nearer to seeing the Government’s long-awaited plan for social care. The need for action could not be more pressing. The Health Foundation says the lack of funding and a recruitment crisis have left hundreds of thousands of elderly without the support they need. There could soon be “care deserts” where no help is available. This a legacy which should shame Theresa May and all who served in her government. Give us power Many drivers want to help the environment by switching to electric cars. But there are far too few charging points. If the Government wants us to go green it needs to invest in the infrastructure.

title: shinnie raring to go for scotland boss
story: New Scotland manager Steve Clarke says departing Aberdeen captain Graeme Shinnie is “raring to go” after being named in his first squad.The midfielder was included alongside Reds centre-backs Scott McKenna and Mikey Devlin.Ex-Dons Ryan Fraser, now at Bournemouth, and Kenny McLean, promoted to the Premier League with Norwich City, also made the grade.Former Kilmarnock boss Clarke is attempting to turn around a Euro  qualying campaign which began with a humiliating loss away in Kazahkstan and a tight win in San Marino.Axed boss Alex McLeish pitched Shinnie in at left-back in Nursultan. He came in for harsh criticism after the - defeat and admitted he feared for his international future.However, Clarke revealed the Derby County-bound -year-old – who played through the pain of an ankle injury in the last two games of the Reds’ season – expressed his love for pulling on the dark blue of Scotland. The gaffer said: “Graeme’s had a great season for Aberdeen and got himself a great move to Derby County.“He’ll be disappointed he’s not going to be with a Premier League team, but it’s still a big move for Graeme.“He’s one of the few I’ve had a conversation with and he’s raring to go.“He said ‘I just love playing for my country’.”Scotland, who are fth in Group I, continue their qualying campaign against Cyprus at Hampden on June , before travelling to Brussels to face group favourites Belgium on June .Shinnie, who has been capped six times for Scotland, is leaving Pittodrie for Derby after agreeing a three-year deal with the Rams.The Pride Park outfit narrowly missed promotion to the English top-flight in Monday’s Premier League play-off final against Aston Villa .Meanwhile, McKenna’s inclusion in Clarke’s maiden squad came as no surprise.The -year-old has become a stalwart for both Aberdeen and his country, and captained the side against Peru last summer.Devlin was a more surprising call-up. The ex-Hamilton Accies skipper was set to make his international debut under McLeish, but was injured in training in November.As a result, the -year-old only made five starts since early November.All in, Clarke has included five uncapped players in his squad.The others are Livingston goalkeeper Liam Kelly and his former Rugby Park charges Stuart Findlay, Greg Taylor and Eamonn Brophy.Clarke said the time of year he is trying to shape his squad meant some of those he wanted to call up were unavailable, with others missing out due to injury.He said: “This squad of players all want to be here and that’s the main thing for me.“It’s dficult for the ones I called last week and tried to convince to cancel weddings that they’ve had organised for the last two years or whatever.“It’s really dficult to do that with people.“We have to be understanding that this is the squad that’s available and I think it’s a good squad.“Hopefully in the games you’ll see that.”Clarke said there are “conversations to be had on every single one of” the players missing from the contingent this time.Among the injured are Kieran Tierney and Ryan Christie , Callum Paterson , David Bates , Ryan Jackand Liam Cooper .Steven Fletcher has asked to be rested, while his Sheffield Wednesday team-mate Barry Bannan wasn’t considered for selection and John Fleckis set to get married on June . Players like Newcastle’s Matt Ritchie remain in international exile.Nevertheless, Clarke thinks he can get two results in his first two matches as Scotland manager, adding: “There’s enough talent in that squad to get results in both games, I’m convinced of that.”

title: flats plan for former aberdeen school delayed

title: hundreds give mixed response a96 dualling plans
story: Hundreds of residents have turned out to view the latest plans to dual the A – and their response has been mixed.The first of four public exhibitions have taken place, giving people a first look at the updated options for the -mile stretch between Huntly and Aberdeen.Transport Scotland has urged residents and community groups to give their views as the Government body pushes forward with its aim of declaring a preferred route before the end of the year. vw, px"  The number of options have been reduced by Transport Scotland, with two potential routes north of Inverurie dropping out of contention.Transport Scotland is pursing six dferent options which could see as many as seven grade-separated junctions built, including at Colpy and Kintore.The remaining option north of Inverurie bypasses the town near the existing road, linking the B Oldmeldrum Road and the B Rothienorman Road, near Portstown area.A Action, a campaign group calling for the Scottish Government to carry out upgrades on the existing route rather than build a new road, says whatever option is chosen will destroy the countryside.Mel Roberts from the group said: “A Action is very pleased to see the blue and green routes north of Inverurie have been deselected.“In our view, however, this does not address what we consider to be a core issue with the north route – the carving out of potentially  miles of new grade-separated dual carriageway through some of the richest farmland and most beautul countryside to be found in the Garioch.“We have also had it confirmed this route would require a -metre-long bridge across the Don Valley at Tavelty, an area rich in wildle, including many protected species.“By comparison, the AWPR Don crossing is  metres.“We continue to call for the reinstatement of the existing A dual corridor as the optimum route for dualling and otherwise upgrading, to address the objectives of improving safety, congestion and shortening journey times.”Another resident who attended the exhibition was Stephen Goodwin, from Kinmuck.He said: “I think a lot of stunning countryside is going to be lost. It feels very destructive.”Garry Nicholl, , from Colpy, also hit out at the current options. He said: “It is a joke. I don’t know how we are able to afford this project.“The Government’s own study said improvements could be made along the existing road.” vw, px"  However, a number of residents expressed their delight at certain options being dropped.Peter Wrangham, from Meikle Wartle, said: “We would have sold our housethe deselected routes had gone ahead as they came very close to our home.“We are happy they have been deselected.”David Burt, project manager for the A dualling project, said Transport Scotland was keen for residents to share their opinions on the routes.He said: “We have had a ied response from people.“We have some people who are pleased we have reduced the number of routes, others are providing feedback on current options and how it is affecting their inidual land.”Mr Burt added: “We are working with the A Action group. We are looking to have a meeting with them so we can discuss their concerns further.“We want people to come to the exhibitions so we can get their feedback face to face and attendance has been quite high.”Michael Matheson, cabinet secretary for transport, infrastructure and connectivity, said: “The Scottish Government has given a clear commitment to dual the A, which will see delivery of around  miles of upgraded road between Inverness and Aberdeen, a huge task but one we are committed to delivering.“As part of that dualling programme, we are taking forward the design work for the -mile stretch of the route between Huntly and Aberdeen.“Having let local communities see and comment on a series of options last October, we have now reduced the number of options for this challenging section of the A and have made some changes to the options being taken forward as a result of the feedback we have received.”A second exhibition at Wyness Hall in Inverurie was scheduled to take place today before moving to Kinellar Community Hall in Blackburn tomorrow and the Gordon Arms Hotel in Huntly on Friday.All are from noon to pm.
